anybody have anything that could help us by chance

Same advice I gave to another team:

If you haven’t started coding yet, I’d start with YAGSL.

We have the same hardware choices as you, so you could peek at our code for some of the YAGSL config specifics. I make no claim that ours is perfect, but it’s clearly working. You will also have to do some methodical reading and direction following, but the result should be a basic functioning bot.

when you say “at the moment” do you mean you don’t have any code for the swerve drive at all or that it isn’t working?
I’d generally recommend yagsl and following the swerve bring up checklist in the documentation.
Will you be the person working on coding this and, if so, how much experience do you have with programming in general?

to clarify you don’t have any programmers or any code able to run on the robot?
If so this sounds like a larger issue than can be easily handled over CD, do you have any nearby local teams who might be willing to help out or send over mentors who could help?

On the swerve drive specific side:
do you have a CAD of the robot?
do you have any members with any background programming (doesn’t necessarily need to be frc specific)?
What is the deadline for the swerve code?

Felix_3507:

Thank you so much but how do I run the code

For other people giving advice: 3507’s competing this week at Green County.

I’d see if you could reach out to another local team for help, but if you can’t land that, start with these two resources from the WPILib team:

Zero to Robot

Software Overview

We only need help on swerve drive

Yeah, Swerve drives are difficult so definitely use yagsl, I’d personally recommend java since the computer science courses at most high schools use java and so you can get input / guidance from the teachers. and that it is also yagsl’s main language iirc.

I hate giving this advice (the step 1 & 2), but I think it’s reasonable here:

  1. Install the needed software onto a laptop
  2. Download our code (link).
  3. Change the constants for the CAN IDs (in src/main/deploy/swerve/*WEEK1/modules) and the encoder offsets.
  4. See if that will drive with the D-pad on an Xbox controller. It should go slowly robot-relative.
  5. Then see if field-relative drive works (requires an add-on gyro to be effective)

You can hopefully accomplish that in about an hour and know if you have any chance of making that work for your robot. If it does, integrate the rest of your mechanisms. If it doesn’t, you’re only one hour closer to the comp and need more help here on CD (or I can help over video conference, provided we can do it in a YPP-compliant way [which means I’d be most comfortable if there’s a mentor or teacher present on your side])

The yagsl documentation has a guide for creating the configuration file:

docs.yagsl.com

Creating your first configuration | YAGSL

tuning webpage: YAGSL Tuning Webpage

Use this combined with the repo @sokoloff shared to get your own config

we use the cad to get the swerve module offsets from the gyroscope (measuring from the center of the bearings to the gyroscope)

If you have more than zero programming skills, I think you should start with the base YAGSL code and just look at our configuration files for help, but not take all of our code. (Mostly because I fear that we have latent bugs that might bite you and our additions might a distraction anyway.)
